This anime has got to be one of the hardest animes to follow that I've watched. The plot was just very complicated and the ending still leaves me with questions. Any way lets dive in.
So the plot is about that Heavens Gate has opened up in South America and I believed it ended up destroying it, and now an organization called the Syndicate is trying to open up Hells Gate in Japan to kill all contractors. What is a contractor? Well a contractor is a person who has traded his conscience for special powers. It gets a lot more complicated and there are a lotmore facts added on to the story or something, but generally for me, it was hard to follow. I'm not gonna tell any spoilers, but the ending was just a huge question mark for me. It left me saying ,"How does that solve anything?" If you already watched it, well you might see what I'm talking about, unless you completely memorized every single plot element and think that there's no plot holes or something. So the ending just left me confused.


Now I'll talk about the characters. Hei, our protagonist, is one of my favorite anime characters and is the only thing keeping this anime alive for me. Without Hei, I would've just probably fallen asleep while watching Darker Than Black. Why I like him? He does like to eat a lot, he's a badass, and I just tend to really like anti heroes in anime. Seriously, antiheros are my favorite type of characters in anime. I guess he also kind of looks like me, but thats just a personal reason. He is also very caring to another one of the characters, Yin. So Yin is a doll and a doll is a person, usually little children, that really don't have a conscience or free will. She's just very quiet cause that's how all of the dolls are in this anime. Some other characters include Huang who really doesn't get much screen time, but there was one episode that talked about his backstory. There's also Mao, who is a contractor in the form of a nekko cause I think his power is to switch bodies or something like that, but there are probably restrictions to it. There are also these two characters named Kurosawa and Kiko who appear in a few episodes throughout the anime. They're just your typical comedic filler characters. Another major character is Misaki who is hunting down Hei cause I guess she's in the FBI or something like that, but she's not actually a bad guy. The last character I'm going to mention is Amber, and she's why I was so confused at the end. I'm not going to tell you cause of spoilers. Hei is the only really good and memorable character in this anime and he's the only reason why I don't hate it.


I enjoyed the action scenes a lot cause it was very fast paced and realistic unlike Dragonball Z where you have the characters stare at each other for 5 minutes until they begin (DBZ is still epic though). It seemed a lot more realistic I suppose. The openings and endings weren't anything too special. I did like the art cause I guess it fit in really good. I watched it in sub and I think it might've been another reason why I didn't enjoy it as much cause I'm a dub fan.


So to sum it up, this anime wasn't anything too special for me cause the plot was very confusing at the end. If you go watch  Darker Than Black Gemini Of The Meteor, the ending there was also kind of like that. If Hei wasn't the main character, I think I might have dropped this anime cause the action scenes while good, probably won't keep me too into the anime if the plot wasn't so confusing. All the other characters were mostly forgettable in my opinion. So yeah, Thx for reading.

The story is set at a time when giant no man’s land known as Heaven’s Gate and Hell’s Gate suddenly appear into the world. It is not literally a gate per se but a very huge piece of land mass completely non-habitable at the opposite side of the Earth. Mysterious things came into being with its appearance. The place itself is feared so much as it led the humans to create a massive wall around it in order to hide the fearsome unknown inside it. Also with it are the appearance of the fake stars (replacing the real ones) and the appearance of the contractors,dolls among others.


The story focuses on the contractor Hei and his group, being agents of a mysterious organization known as the “Syndicate,” they do detective works, assassinations, intelligence gathering, and in many circumstances fight with other organizations. 


The beginning was very confusing as not much is explained to the various mysteries revolving the world of Darker than Black, the pacing is more like a snail pace and the series are divided into several arcs each having at least 2 episode that are interdependent from the other arcs, it could very well be standalones but each offer hints that when sum up together actually tells the story. While some arcs may be a bit uninteresting, there are several others – the one that focuses on the actual story are very well done. The pacing eventually gets better during the middle part of the series with the introduction of some key characters and groups that will become the main focus of the series towards the end.


The mysteries surrounding the Gates is actually the series strongest element in my opinion, almost nothing at all is revealed about it but the series actually spend a lot of time with the characters and organizations trying to solve the mystery behind it, some of which will succeed and others will not but it all comes with a prize and I applaud this setup because I’m with the people with the mentality that some mysteries are better not explained (let the viewers imagine the rest), explaining it only kills the enjoyment, the thrill, and the tension that comes with it. 


The animation is conveyed in a more serious tone. The background art is rather bland but there is something about it that will make the viewers says that it is done in style and of high production values. The same thing can be said with the character designs; the characters are designed in such a way to appeal to the more mature audiences.  The animation is fluid and life-like especially the movements of the characters and the fights scenes are very creatively choreograph which sometimes can be visually impressive.


Both the Opening and Ending Themes are great, very catchy and enjoyable to listen. The soundtracks on the other hand are pretty decent which are good to listen when watching the series. As for voice acting, the actors did a pretty good job giving life to the characters they portrayed in the series. I especially like the voice of Kuichi Hidenobu as Hei, he made Hei into someone very cool sounding as well as a dependable. 


Almost all the characters in Darker Than Black are likeable. Hei as the main character has some very good character development. At first he is very cold, lifeless, emotionless, but as the story progress, he eventually started showing emotions and more human character. The same can be said for the other characters on his group, at first they all act like every day is just another day of work but as bits of their histories are eventually revealed, they all acted looking for each another especially in their most challenging times. My favorite character beside Hei is Yin, she is called a "doll" also being cold at first, lifeless, emotionless at first but her development is also quite spectacular on the end. The series boast some really huge number of characters, all-in-all they did a very good job in portraying their respective roles be it major or minor ones.


The idea of contractors doing "remuneration" as payment for using their powers is a very refreshing concept. I particularly like it because it post several limitations to the users which generally mean that they cannot just go around and fight as they will adding a more realistic feel to the fights and made the characters more vulnerable instead of being invincible and all powerful. This check and balances made the series a great find.


The series is full of mystery, action, secret organizations, sci-fi concepts, and great characters, add to it are good production value, nice animation, a well designed story and a carefully constructed plot. As a whole, Darker Than Black is very solid and fun to watch amidst the slow pace in the early parts of the story and an ending that leaves a lot to be desired which comes up pretty open ended. As for my final note, the series is recommended for viewers with interest on the aforementioned themes above.

So "Darker than Black" drew me in by the title."Darker than Black"?That's a pretty cool title.Anywho,this series is okay,for a series that explains little to nothing, has almost no character development and is a little overall confusing, it does a good job to entertain.
The story is pretty complicated to begin with. Some explosion occurs five years prior and we lose Latin America(might be the other way around though 'cause I'm forgetful)and then the sky disappears and they build a gate around Tokyo to keep them away from some forbidden area. Oh and some supernatural beings that look like humans appear that are called "Contractors".We enterthe life of one; Hei and his adventurous of fighting and killing pretty graphically other contractors.

I can say it's pretty interesting, the episodes are in arcs and only midway to the show they start to have some little consistency and follow some story. Other than that it's just Hei going along with the orders he is given to "eliminate" some useless material.


Pros:

So let's start with the art. The art is pretty, it's obviously on a low budget but however it manages to be nice to look at.Character design is nice and very beautiful.The art's a bit strange though since they supposedly lost their sky and have a counterfeit which at nighttime is green.Yes people,green,the sky is green at night with lots of fake stars.

There is one element I really liked that I only noticed it when it actually started to happen it real life.The element of rain.It rains a lot for a large amount of episodes of this series and not for dramatic reasons,it just rains. Like Hei steps out of his house to go buy some groceries and it starts raining.The rain added a very mysterious and cool atmosphere to the show.

It has very enjoyable action, nice movements,interesting opponents. The opponents actually have a personality here other than the usual we see in such genres and most of them are very likeable.

The characters are fairly interesting,Hei is shady,literally,he shows a different personality according to whom he speaks to.He really is this gloomy,serious dude but to most he is this shy,clumsy and polite fellow who always says hello.Yin is promising but we don't get much about her. Huang is much more likable then at first.The cop lady is forgettable and rather annoying.Her presence serves nothing at all to the show.To be honest all the contractors are much more interesting then the "normal" people.

The music is okay, the OP is nice, done by the Abington Boys School,they usually have nice tracks.The EDs are forgettable.The OST is okay,it has a variety of music from jazz, to pop to rock.


Cons:

There isn't much explained,ever.Like you watch the whole thing expecting something to happen but it doesn't.Even the last episode is like...totally random.I mean literally, it's just random.

There is some comic relief by a detective and his secretary?(I'm not sure what she was).They were pretty random too, like you have all this gore and fighting going on and then them who look like they came out of Lucky Star or something.They added nothing to the story either,it seemed that  the plot was aiming for something more serious but these guys just blew that away.

The use of CGI is annoying.It's used for the cars, but you see a lot of cars here and everytime I just wanna bang my head against the wall it's so bad.

The characters are ALL promising but none of them get the attention they deserve.Okay Hei does,but you really don't understand anything by what they give you!


Overall you have this promising plot that looks likes it's going somewhere but doesn't(and I heard the second season is just a different arc) and promising characters that are left hanging on a cliff.This story tried to be good, it succeed in many things but failed in many others.It really is all over the place, like the final episodes are so darn complex, it's like the writer wanted to say all these things but didn't have the time so tried to explain everything is one episode of 20 minuets.

Darker than Black is enjoying and if you choose to watch this you will be entertained there is no doubt about that.But don't expect anything too deep and don't expect any conclusion 'cause nothing is ever concluded or explained.

Darker than Black is one of the best of its kind. The anime covers not only incredibly visually pleasing action sequences, but a good story to boot (something I find difficult to see meshed together). 
One of the most crucial elements in creating an action anime is to be sure the viewers like what they'll be seeing a lot of: action. Darker than Black, a product of Aniplex, never disappointed me once. The fights are fluid, speeds wavering between slow and quick, and seldom include distractions. They're made expertly to keep the interest of the viewer in tact, and they never last too long. Saygoodbye to three episodes of the same battle in the rain, because this anime keeps fights short and sweet- only frequent.


I thought the action sequences would be enough to appreciate, but I was pushed further into my gratitude with the accompanying music. Yoko Kanno, musical composition for Cowboy Bebop (and a whole lot more), was the mastermind behind the art here, and oh how it shows. A few of the songs, sound similar to what you may have heard in Cowboy Bebop, or hear if you've never seen the show, even bringing back the incomparable crackled voice of Mai Yamane. 


With the quality of the production being high, high, high, all that's left is to dig into the story itself. While the characters play typical roles of another action anime you may have seen (go on, pick one), they manage to be clearly defined characters, rather than just stamps for the sake of the plot. While some recurring side roles may be a little weaker, I feel it's safe to say they aren't too bothersome. The focus veers away from their roles anyhow. 


I was greatly impressed with the story. While at first, I felt the plot was left with a few holes, and kept quiet and vague just because that's what action anime typically does best, I found as the story progressed, that it's all done of purpose, and with very good reason. I'm staying away from summaries and spoilers here, so I'm going to cut it short, but I was overwhelmed with joy at discovering an action anime that keeps it's motives hidden to reveal them when it makes sense to be revealed. Frustration played little to no part in my watching of the show. 


Granted, there may be some weaker points, such as; why does it take until the last six episodes to start gently laying down the point to why things have been going on (a little more information might have been helpful before, but at least I wasn't left in the dark, or pummeled at the very end, right?), or why did that man's hand suddenly become a fourth the size of his face (the wonderful animation flaws of Aniplex. I'm pretty sure I spotted a mystery dot appearing and disappearing for a few seconds on a white wall, too). But for an action anime, I still remain impressed.


Good work, Darker than Black! 


-shoujokiss7

First off you must trust me when i say, Darker Than Black, is one of the Amine that you are better off not watching. If you condemn yourself to such a miserable action, it'll be a waste of your precious time doing laundry or anything trivial for that matter.
    Originally I had Darker Than Black on my Dropped List, however due to its excessive occurrence on people's favorite list i decided to give it another chance. And Oh God i wish i hadn't. Starting with it's pathetic Story, Hell's and Heavens Gate appear and alongside their appearance theappearance of contractors and certain beings called dolls. You soon feel the presence of an organization also know as the syndicate lurking in the shadows, several other factors emerge such as foreign intelligence, foreign organizations, all these playing the role of disrupting the peace in the city of Tokyo. All this happening without the knowledge of the citizens, thanks to the process of Memory Erasal, which you do not capture a glimpse off , through the entire series.You lose track of whose working with who shortly after the beginning of the series, and things starts to mess up. Several Unanswered Questions and Unjustified Events start to pile up, and you innocently believe that all these will be answered later on in the series. You realize your falling flat on your face towards the last 4-5 episodes of the series where you thought its time things got clear, and they don't. In the end you will sit for a few minutes trying to figure out what the hell did just happen. Overall all the writer really messed this up. His inability to conduct reasons for the events that occur throughout the series, and the lack of consistency of the story line is crystal clear. In my opinion the writer sought interest in various big ideas within several different Anime and tried to mold them all into a single storyline, which in turn turned out to be a serious failure. The storyline and it's many details and unanswered questions, proved to require a lot of work and time to attend too, therefore it was decided to lay off matters with a quick and irrelevant finish.


    Concerning the Art, am not that much of an expert,however i can say they've done a good job throughout the series, except for the times when they used Computer Generated Images for cars and vehicles. 


    About the Music well its the most decent thing about the series. Various soundtracks serve the role of emphasizing the impact of events onto you. 


  Another major failure in the series are the characters. Although stated numerous times throughout the series that contractors and dolls have no soul therefore have no emotions, they are the ones that show most emotions. I don't know what the writer wanted to accomplish with this paradox, however it will leave you in a state of dilemma questioning the actions of each character. Another major detail i should point out is the unjustified behavior of the characters, you simply wont get the reasons behind their actions, or the basis behind their relationships.


   Well i must admit, if it was not for the few and brief (and i emphasize both) moments of pleasure, the level of enjoyment would have been 0.


   In the end i know many of you will hate me for this review. however i gave my honest opinion about it.



 I forgot the excessive Pizza Hut product placement.

In four word : confusing yet brilliantly intirguing.
(review in short at bottom)
Story : at first Darker than Black starts out really well in terms of story, introducing the characters and building up to the climax ect. But I found that at one point they threw a few too many confusing terms at you such as anti-gate matter particles ... so much so that I got a bit confused when the ending came around. However by the time the series had ended I had a basic understanding of the ending. Despite the confusion it is possible to follow the story and completley enjoy the characters andtheir exploits. 7/10


Art : I frankly love the drawing style of this series, all the characters are very well drawn and all of the individual techniques of the contractors are portrayed well. Another highlight of this series is the animation, because this series is quite heavily combat based you should expect great fight scenes. Darker than Black doesn't dissapoint, the fighting excells with fluid and precise animation. 9/10


Sound : Darker than Black has some pretty good music (especially opening one , Abingdon Boys School - Howling). Both openings fit the series well along with the endings. Even the osts are very impressive and match the dramatic and light parts of the series. 8/10


Character : for a resonably short series it's quite impressive how much development each character gets for example you have Hei's past at war, Yin as a child and Huang getting decieved by a woman. All of the character development leads to an intersting and entertaining plot. Darker than Black has a large amount of interesting minor characters, even if you don't get much information on them you still get the enjoyment of witnessing their powers as a contractor.8/10


Overall/Enjoyment : overall this series is a pleasure to watch and is quite mentally stimulating. It has great art and sound along with a host of interesting and individual characters. You may get a tad confused but it's easy enough to rewatch for a better uderstanding. A smart and well developed series. 8/10

WOO Darker than Black. Despite what you've probably heard about the second season being terrible (key words "what you may have heard" not that "it is") the first season is just one of those super solid shows. In the show an unexplained event happens prior to the main story that basically gave a lot of people different kinds of powers (super cut and dry, I don't need to elaborate much more). Said people are called contractors, as they must hold a contract of habitually doing something every time they use their powers. The synopsis is unexplained but simple, but the story is rather sporadic. Themain arc focuses on a group of police officers looking for contractors in Tokyo outside of a walled area called Hell's Gate. Amidst their journeys they frequently come across the protagonist named Hei, an assassin who works for a contractor group called the Syndicate. First let's talk about Hei, he's what drives the show, and while stoic, his quiet personality fits well with what he's supposed to be doing. Not much is revealed about his past, but it hints at it with his many experiences with other contractors, another guiding factor of the show. The plot adds to this as well, as it feels like a typical cop drama meets X-men type deal, and is a fairly unique skeleton for the plot that adds to the experience. The action throughout the show is entertaining, but it's redundant that I should say that, but I liked that most fights were pretty different from each other, as all contractors who fight Hei have different abilities. Speaking of the abilities, the environments, action, and characters are all extremely well animated, drawn, and colored, and that's perhaps the best part of the show.The only problems I had with the show was the constant serious tone, only to get a moderately forced bad chemistry detective duo later in the season. And as I said before the show never fully explains what happened prior to the series chronology or why it's significant (i.e. everything about Hei's sister) and that was frustrating for me personally. And that means only one thing, I have to attempt season 2. However I would recommend this anime to pretty much anyone, the plot is balanced even if they skim over too much that needs explanation, characters interesting, and it's very pretty. Good show.

Before you watch the anime, it'll probably make more sense if you speak mandarin. Remember that Hei means black in Chinese and Bai means white.
Overall: Animes similar to Darker than Black are truly very rare. It is unique with its mind blowing awesomeness. It doesn't try to buff itself with ridiculous power ups like Bleach or Naruto, but rather uses its great storyline to keep the viewer interested. It explores the idea of conscience in humans while mixing in amazing action scenes, original antagonists with unique and non-cliche abilities.
Character: Most character are developed enough to make you sympathize with them, those who aren't developed areundeveloped for a reason. At least it feels that way rather than leaving the viewer wondering why they were there in the first place.


Sound: I loved all four ops and eds,they are bands that had performed for mainstream animes like Bleach, Naruto and Gundam Seed Destiny. If you liked the anime, you will almost definitely love the music.


Art: Because it is relatively new, it has great action scenes and they're not completely computer generated that leaves you with a cheap sense of over budgeting like blassreiter.


Story: Amazing, anything i would try to use to support would be considered a spoiler. But still, the character development in the main characters are amazing and the ending is original. Its not a plushy forced ending to make u happy, nor is it an failed attempt at originality that makes you wish you had dropped it, the ending is...

The first season, and the majority believe that it's the best season. You get to see Hei being ridiculously good and what he does, giving you a sense of awe. Whenever he shows up, your heart starts to race because everything had lead up to that moment and you know he's going to make something happen. 
Seriously, watch this show. It has gore and violence, but nothing any more excessive than what the story allows. Something I really have to note, Hei, is not invincible or unbeatable like other protagonists who just blindly punch enemies into submission. The protagonist often retreats just like the antagonist.Often is key here, and when he does, you realise that something about him is... different.


EDIT: Updated for accuracy and details


Story: Excellent, while some might not like how it ended or how information was revealed, it never needed to be revealed in any other way. We see things happening through the eyes of Hei, and Misaki, who you could say are on opposite sides, but you don't know who's good and who's bad until the end. I thought the story was perfect, but I have to give it a 9 simply because some things won't please everyone.


Hei was a killer when he was younger, before he ever got any powers, because of his sister, but continued even after she disappeared. He's an interesting character and he's one of my favourite to watch simply because I'm constantly impressed by what he says or does, and how well he fights. He's not indestructible, but he is usually tactical. But! Every special power user, or contractor has to pay a kind of price, from eating a flower to drinking blood in one disturbing case.


The thing about this show is characters and character development, but I'll get into that later.


Art: They save most of their money for the fight scenes, and it's worth it. It's amazing to watch people fight up close where the slightest touch could result in someone's head being blown off. 


Sound: Perfect, I love the voice overs in English, I love the sound effects, environment sounds and audio tracks. As soon as the Black Reaper shows up, music kicks in and an intense fight follows.


Enjoyment: I've watched this show 3 times already and still love it. The OVAs are great too and generally have to do with Hei and Yin's relationship


Once again, some people may not like how it ended. I just wish it never did end. Easily above 9.5/10, which after rounding, 10/10

So what happens when you expose a group of people to a supernatural and unexplained phenomenon that breaks out of blue in our small small world? Sometimes they die. Sometimes they get insane. Most often they obtain supernatural powers.
At a glance Darker than Black is same old formula: an unexplained occurs, people magically obtain equally magical abilities and then Professor Xavier, pardon me, someone with enough brain figures out a way to brings such people together and put them to good use, for better or for worse. And then some choose path of evil, some choose path of good and some choose to be asuperpower for hire. In Darker than Black it's mostly the latter.


Plot.

Like I mentioned above, Darker than Black may seem like an old formula but yet it has new taste to it. And so two mysterious anomalies known as Hell's and Heaven's Gate appear out of blue in two distant parts of the world, rendering areas around them into completely isolated areas somewhat akin to silent zones. What's more, somehow natural stars are gone from the sky. Meanwhile more and more people start manifesting supernatural abilities. As Darker than Black starts, there is little known initially about either Contractors, or Gates, or the link between the former and the stars. What makes this anime different from others with same concept is that the nature of Contractor is defined by word itself. They have to pay - sometimes severely - for the powers they use. And so following a contractor BK201/Hei who's working for mysterious syndicate we learn more about the world, the contractors and their types and his own personal quest.


There is no linear plot from point A to point B whatsoever. The story is, by and large, quite episodic, built in 2-3 episode arcs. What ties all these episodes together is Hei's personal quest rather than any particular events. That being said, the episodes offer diversity. We have episodes that focus on main characters, those which focus on supporting characters and those which are there just for the sake of humor. I can't say that in the end we learn everything, but most important questions will be answered - and rather satisfyingly at that.


Art.

The art is very solid, offering clean designs and vivid, lively colors. The surroundings are rendered beautifully, with full attention to light effects. Special effects pertaining superpowers are done well: nothing extraordinary but quite nice, with smooth animation. The character design is not exactly breathtaking but it's memorable enough.


Sound.

The soundtrack composed by Yoko Kanno is absolutely fabulous. Darker than Black sports a wide range of ambient music, ranging from airy jazzy tunes to gorgeous instrumental pieces, my favourite being Yin no Piano. Battle and action themes are adrenaline-filled and will please rock lovers. The voice acting is great, especially for the protagonist. You can always hear the switching of his personality, each "mode" having a very specific manner of speech and voice tone.


Characters.

I loved practically all the characters, and this anime presents quite a party of truly different ones. There's quiet and perpetually melancholic medium, there's an awkward cop, there's a perverted middle-aged detective, there's a Bond-like agent and much more. Hei/BK201 undoubtedly steals the show with his unidentified personality; his professional and private personalities being like black and white and you'll be always wondering who he truly is, why he is like that, and whether he was the same prior the events of anime. The antagonists of the series could be sympathized with, which in fact makes certain episodes only more dramatic.


Overall.

DtB is a truly interesting anime which manages to combine a solid plotline with episodic narration. It has action, it has mystery, it has drama and it has humor and it has some bittersweet romance, believe it or not. Most importantly it's a classic, winning formula with a little fresh twist that definitely deserves your attention.

DTB starts off with a great two episode introduction, which exposes the various premises and general state of things with contractors, dolls, hell's gate, fake stars, etc. The story is divided into 25 episodes, usually with every two episodes constituting a story involving the main character, Hei, and his interactions with other contractors, dolls, and people. Many of these stories contain flashbacks highlighting and explaining parts of a character's past. 
The series contains a central plot involving the appearance of contractors, hell's gate, and a mysterious event involving heaven's gate that occurred in the past. This, however, is usually kept in the periphery, mentioned onlybriefly from episode to episode despite being the gravity of the whole story until the final. The main plot is foreshadowed and explained a little halfway through the series in a two-parter analogous to cowboy bebop's jupiter jazz: while spike's past is one of the most important things of the story in cowboy bebop, the plot follows various mini-events that occur, hinting at what's going on halfway through the series, and concluding with the finale. this is similar to what happens in DTB. The episodes not related to the main plot, however, are almost always interesting and enjoyable.


There are some really cool ideas in this anime, my favorite being the motif of Hei's dissonance between cold rational and emotion. He is a really great product of the show in terms of character development, and the finale does a great job of coming to terms with this theme. Some other ideas seem underdeveloped though, such as the replacement of stars w/ fake stars, and the strong concentration on Hei distracts from other characters (such as Amber) who I wish were developed more.


The fight sequences are pretty cool. The animation for them is done well, and though the duration of the fights are usually pretty short, it's always interesting to see the different contractor's abilities and obeisances, and how they relate to the characters themselves. The show is not action-driven though, and the fight sequences really serve mainly to complement the characters/story.


Probably the most frustrating thing about this anime is the vague introduction of the premises, which should have been explained more sufficiently and earlier on. I went through the series (25 episodes) in about 4 days. Some episodes are better than others, but overall its a great anime worth watching with some interesting ideas worth thinking about.

Superpowers, noir, action, suspense, and secrets. These are the ingredients to the recipe for Darker Than Black. This anime is undeniably familiar when it comes to it's concepts and some blatant influences, but it's not completely unoriginal, and it's not bad either.
Story - 8/10
The story of Darker Than Black is based around Hei, a super-powered agent working for a shady organization known as The Syndicate. The show takes things from here and slowly, very, very slowly, details and opens up the plot, setting, and backstories of characters. This is done in an episodic structure similar to Cowboy Bebop or Ghost in the Shell: Stand AloneComplex; with some quality episodes outside of the main plot, but also a little bit of filler too.


The central concept of the universe this anime takes place in is Contractors. Years prior to the beginning of the story, a world-changing event occurs and the result was Contractors. These people, not considered human or capable of emotion, have powers that come with a "contract" price to pay every time they are used. This concept is a unique take on super-powers and it becomes something of an event every time you get to see a new Contractor.


I mentioned things open up slowly, and it wasn't a problem for me, but it definitely will be for some. You better be ready to pay attention when you're watching Darker Than Black, because all but one episode are two-parters. Lots of stuff is left unexplained for periods of time but when it comes time to get to the details, there is no shame in the time the show takes to get into it. This was something of a drawing point though. The mystery of everything that is going on and wondering about it is part of what makes watching this anime so interesting. Interesting may be the buzz word that goes off in most people's heads often during the course of most episodes.


The main complaint I could have with the plot here is that it gets so interesting that I found myself clamoring for a bit more. It was good, but felt like it could have been better at the same time. The last episode leaves lots of things inconclusive, a risky note to end a story on. There are also lots of flashbacks, and it's not always obvious what time the story is taking place.


Animation - 9/10


I'm a fan of Bones' animation. This isn't their best work and it may not be the most fitting for the serious tone of the show, but I'll be damned if it isn't high quality. Character design stands out very often, with plenty of unique people to look at and Hei's mask being something that immediately feels iconic upon seeing it. Action scenes are full of breathtaking moments and polished movement flowing through great scenery in a usually dark color palette. All the powers you see bring a nice level of variety to the stuff Bones gets to pull off with the animation and they do get quite creative at times. The only thing to knock with the animation here is the style seems a little unfitting for the tone of the show. For an anime called Darker Than Black, with such a serious tone, I think something apart from the safe standard approach could have paid off big here.


Sound - 8/10


Yoko Kanno composed the soundtrack, which is usually all there is to say. This isn't her best work either but it's above average for sure. The opening themes are great, the ending theme is pretty basic, and the bulk of the OST that plays during episodes ranges from decent to amazing. Many of the tunes get repeated like with most anime, and it's for better with some and for worse with others. Most of the main songs that you'll recognize hearing are for better though. There's also some very high quality music in the final episodes that probably should have been used more often. It's a very good soundtrack but at times it feels unfitting, with some songs that seem like Cowboy Bebop throwaways.


The voice acting overall is pretty good. There aren't any specific performances that stood out, it's more of a top to bottom solid cast than anything else.


Characters - 8/10


This is where things get odd. A common note people tend to make with Darker Than Black is that lots of characters other than the main cast seems to develop better. I'm inclined to agree. Even lots of the one-off Contractors seem to be extremely interesting in certain episodes. I think the problem here is that when it came time for backstory on the main characters, it was a good starting point, but backstory isn't always enough. Huang for example, isn't a Contractor, isn't really a main character, but turns out being very well developed with backstory episodes and changes that can't go unnoticed as the show goes on. Misaki Kirahara and Mao on the other hand, two characters with potentially the most interesting viewpoints of the show (one is a cop tracking Hei, the other is trapped in a cat's body) and more plot importance don't get nearly enough time in comparison.


This wasn't a problem with the protagonist Hei, as the entire duality of his undercover and Contractor persona was fascinating and becomes important to the resolution of the show itself. Yin however, had a fantastic arc on her backstory which remains one of my favorites of the series, but her character never really goes anywhere after this, and the episode was at the halfway point of the show. It's weird because the portrayal of Yin is that she's the second most important main character but it never really feels like that's the case.


I could go on about people like November 11, Amber, Havoc, and others, but it becomes apparent early on that while characters you can enjoy who develop are plentiful in Darker Than Black, it may not be the ones you expect. It makes scoring this category difficult, because there are plenty of interesting personalities, but the ones that feel like they should be more important aren't.


Overall - 8/10


Drawing clear inspirations from things both within anime and outside it, Darker Than Black is an admirable attempt at bringing so many ideas to the table that it would seem difficult not to enjoy it on some level. There are crazy fights, a puzzle surrounding the story, and even some humor, though the latter was something I found lacking given the business-like nature of the show. At it's core Darker Than Black finds strength in the animation of it's action scenes and the mystery of it's plot.

Story: The story does a great job of pulling together the characters presented at a steady pace. By the 15th episode you can feel the gravitational pull between the characters and the main themes and story arcs begin to be explored. Contractors are heartless and logical, Dolls are intuitive and expressionless and humans are...well...human, lol. All parties mentioned are pushed to the limits of morality, self-interest and evolution/change. The beauty in the story to me is its ability to make you feel and pull for two people on opposing sides. The paradoxical nature of the interactions leave you in a gray area of morality withoutthe appalling feeling of choosing the better of two evils. The realness hit me to the core and when I finished the first season I was ecstatic to find more. I dove right into the OVAs and the second season, but I'll save that for when I write those reviews. The last point I will make is that the story does a great job of not being overly predictable or redundant.


Art: I enjoyed the character designs, the colors and tones.


Sound: I enjoy Yoko Kanno's work and that holds true for the score used in Darker Than Black. A couple of tracks that come to mind are "Water Forest", "Go Dark", "Guy", "Contractor" and this one song that is not on the OST. It comes on when you first meet November 11, its also heard in a few random action sequences.


Character: I gave character a 10 and story a 9 because I fell in love with so many characters. The story as a whole was great but the characters themselves are written extremely well and I felt genuinely interested in what was on the horizon for each character as their individual stories proceeded and intersected.


Enjoyment: I give it a 9 because I feel this anime is a 9.5 and a 9 in no way takes away with how much I enjoyed this anime. I do plan to re-watch this series multiple times. Definitely an instant classic in my library.


Overall: I stand by my 9.5 that I stated earlier. I think I can't give it 10s across the board because I feel too bias and I feel that I need a season 3 or some more OVAs to satisfy my interest. The music and art frame the anime and live true to the name. The story and characters pull you in and keep your interest. I enjoyed all the action, the trippy/cool powers contractors and dolls have. An overall great experience!


Thanks for reading. This is my very first review. I'll be back to finish off the Darker Than Black Gaiden and Darker than Black: Gemini of the Meteor reviews. Peace

Darker Than Black is one tight package. It's a highly enjoyable series with an intriguing premise, a plethora of send-ups to the rich history of anime, spot-on art direction and a set of story arcs that are vast in scope yet end before overstaying their welcome. 
	The premise of the story, where in select humans are given super powers in a catastrophic accident, is not particularly unique. However, the show manages to tackle the same topic that many have before without feeling stale at all. Although the idea is not new, Darker Than Black manages to stay fresh by examining the dilemmas of its richcast of characters in believable and interesting ways. Nearly all of the the characters have fleshed out back-stories, many of which are very compelling. Even characters who initially seem 2-dimensional and unlikable, like the syndicate affiliated Huang, come into their own and become extremely sympathetic.\n
	The story even has a sense of irony and poetic justice, as the "contractors" (as these super humans are called) must make payments for their powers. This may consist of smoking a cigarette, aligning objects into obscure patterns, composing a poem, or a whole plethora of bizarre and sometimes fitting punishments. The reason for these payments, like many other aspects of the plot (including the catastrophe that gave these individuals their powers) is kept fairly vague. It's a decision for the better undoubtedly, as it creates an air of mystery and confusion throughout the series. It's best to not dwell on the things that are unexplained and simply enjoy the narrative as it unfolds with the scarce explanation that is provided. Really, I still don't know exactly what the story was about, and I'm completely fine with that. All I know is that it was a pretty damn good ride- one that I won't soon forget.\n
	The other piece that makes Darker Than Black so enjoyable is the quality of art, music and voices. Bones studio, most famous for their Fullmetal Alchemist adaptations, are behind this series and bring their accomplished and highly professional look to it. Character models are consistent and expressive, backgrounds are atmospheric and convincing, and there is nary a moments of weak animation to take you out of the experience. The overall visual tone is extremely even too, avoiding the pitfalls of low-budget middle sections that many series find themselves in. Opting out of cartoonish anime "shorthand", the series is a decidedly serious looking one, if not necessarily always as serious feeling show, as moments of levity are strategically placed throughout the narrative. \n
	Darker Than Black, for all of its strengths, does leave i bit to be desired. I haven't watched the second series yet, but honestly a series should stand on its own without using the possibility of a second as a crutch. Without revealing anything, I will say that it doesn't end on its strongest foot, leaving you a bit high and dry. Also, I kind of with things had gotten a bit more bizarre and surreal. There were certainly signs pointing in that direction, and even plot elements that would make contextual sense for things to get more psychological. This isn't the mindfuck that it could have been, but I suppose not all things can be. One can dream.

What happens when some people gain supernatural powers while losing all emotions and remain solely with pure logic? In the world of DTB these are contractors. In an effort to survive, normal humans bind them under paid contracts and use them as spies or hitmen. This is the basic storyline of the series. 
I found the series pretty interesting. Although slow paced to begin with as the story progresses it takes you with it. The story opens a lot of questions but fortunately they are all solved by the end and if you really like the story you can always continue with the second season.
Thecharacters are interesting and have their stories revealed in a way that fits the story perfectly. Introduction of new characters is consistent with the plot but not frequent.\n
I would not recommend it to people who don't like sci-fi or far reached scenarios. But if you are a fan of the genre and you are looking for a pleasant short series that wont leave you dissapointed you should watch it!

I won't bother with the synopsis and get straight to the review, hope you find it useful.
	Story: The first 22 episodes of the series are made of eleven 2 episode story arcs, each focusing on one or two characters. These stories are undoubtedly the best part in the darker than black franchise. 2 episodes give just enough time to tell a well developed  story, and I'm always surprised how much the series be accomplished in merely 2 episodes. The content of each arc are never repetitive and have something new to offer each in arc. 
Thelast 2 episodes of the series that deal with the final showdown are rather disappointing in comparison, and left a lot of unawsered questions , and the second season does little to help and add more to the mess. The back story of Hei was only briefly touched on through segments of flashbacks, even though it was essential to understanding the character. The anime had perfect chance in episode 23 for flashbacks, but instead we were given a "day before war episode" where nothing really happened.



	Characters:  The main character Hei has the cold distant deameanor all slick assasins in anime have, but combines depth and sensititvity while keeping his coolness intact, making him easily one of my favourite anime Characters. Even though his persona as a kind, introverted partimer completely differs from his persona as a ruthless assasin ; his action makes you realize they are undoubtedly the same person.



 There is also a large cast of supporting character, and most of them are surprisingly fleshed out given the amount of screen time they had. Personally, I find it hard to dislike any of them. The anime never waste anytime when it comes to characterization, despite being an action anime, the series focus more on the character interaction  instead of fighting.



 One thing that deserves mentioning is how easily characters die in the show, which is pretty fustrating. Just when you start to sympathisze with the characters, they get stabbed to death by ice pricks, dissapear into dreams or bleed to death on the street.  I don't know if it's to show the unpredictabily of death or if the producer are too lazy to deal with accumulating amount of side characters.



	Action: As most reviewers will tell you, DtD have great action scene with fluid animation, that are well choreographed. Compare to other contracter hei's electrical power are less spectacular, causing him to be overwhelmed most of the time during a fight. Forcing him to act like a genuine assasin using his wit and stealth. preventing the fight scene from degenerating to mere comparison between power level.



	Overall DtD is a very enjoyable anime, despite it's disappointing ending. You might have to watch twice it to know what's exactly going on in the story, but the character interaction and fight scene itself are very enjoyable even if the story is hard to follow. If you enjoy dark anime, that does not dwell into the realm of emo-ness and melodrama, definitely give this a try.

Be warned, this review may contain /spoilers/.
Darker Than BLACK is an anime produced by BONES, released in Japan in the year 2007. The anime centres on its four main protagonists, during several, short story arcs.
The four main characters are Hei, Yin, Huang, and Mao. They all have Chinese names – these are codenames. The only actually Chinese person in the group is Hei (whose name means “black” in Chinese). Yin is Finnish (her name means “silver”), Huang is Japanese (his name means “yellow”), and Mao’s nationality is unknown (his name means “cat”). All the characters have different personalities and distinct ways of acting. Huang, Hei,and Yin’s histories are all touched on in the first season of Darker Than BLACK, while Mao’s receives less attention. His background is only touched on in depth in the second season (Ryuusei no Gemini). The side characters are also interesting, with their own personalities and motives. In particular, I like Kirihara Misaki, a policewoman who could be called the main character of the “opposing” force to Hei and his team.


Darker Than BLACK has an interesting setting; futuristic Tokyo, where the appearance of “Hell’s Gate” has caused beings called “contractors” and “dolls” to emerge into the world. Contractors are individuals with special abilities, such as the ability to create lightning or teleport, and they can use these powers at will. However, they must perform their remuneration during or after they use their power – this can be anything from eating cigarettes to breaking one’s fingers, and is usually associated to something the contractor has previously done. There are some contractors (like Mao) who have fulfilled their contract and therefore do not need to perform their remuneration, although this is rare. Contractors are very logical individuals – they have detached themselves from their emotions and any ties they had with family members and friends. Dolls are spiritual mediums that have the power to “see” using specific mediums, like glass or water, while being invisible to others. They have no emotion whatsoever and are incapable of making decisions for themselves. It has been shown that dolls are “manufactured” and sold as products and goods, particularly in underground organizations like the mafia or yakuza.


Hei and Mao are both contractors. Hei can produce and conduct lightning, and Mao can possess the bodies of animals. Notably, Mao lost his human body and is therefore stuck in the form of a black cat. Yin is a doll whose medium is water. Huang is the only human in the group – he hates both contractors and dolls and makes the point of voicing this periodically. Hei is an interesting contractor, since he doesn’t have a remuneration and still makes most decisions based on human emotion. Reasons for this are revealed near the end of season one.


In the first episode, we are introduced to Li Shungsheng, a gentle student from China, who is actually a masquerading Hei. Things get complicated when we learn Hei works for “the Syndicate”, a mysterious organization with an unknown agenda. Darker Than BLACK is primarily a series of short, two-episode story arcs, with the longest one being three episodes, at the end. Although it is told in such a fashion, it never feels episodic – the plot manages to interconnect the various arcs into a bigger plot. The arcs are something like threads in the tapestry that is Darker Than BLACK, with every character being introduced for a reason – to further the plot and so that we may learn more about our four main characters. The arcs are interesting enough to catch the viewer’s attention and cause is to want to push through the end, to see how exactly the stories are connected.


The characters develop as the series go on, Yin in particular. From an emotionless robot she becomes something that could be called a “human being”, albeit a quiet one. Hei also shows signs of development, which is something even the characters point out. Huang and Mao are somewhat static characters, although Huang’s lack of development is a given when you find out his past. All the characters are realistic and life-like, and all are interesting in their own right. Watching Hei juggle his real persona and the personality of Li Shungsheng at the same time is amusing and adds some comic relief to an otherwise very serious and dark anime. Darker Than BLACK makes you think.


Overall, Darker Than BLACK is a fluid, interesting, emotional ride that takes you on a rollercoaster through the depths of the human mind, prejudice, and relationships.

Before I write this I want to state that this is my opinion and that you may agree or disagree at your own will.
Review:
Darker than black was one of my favorite anime for a long time until I rewatched it. When I saw it for a second time I was pretty disappointed by how much I didn't realize it wasn't that good. The initial plot was awesome where all of these contractors with special powers did different contracts for money but then the plot that our character is wrapped up in is pretty lame. If you want to watch for the fights then have atthis anime the fights are well done with excellent animation. The intro fits the anime and is pretty catchy at points. Character wise our MC is badass cold hearted guy but his plot in the story I think is done pitifully. The side characters are almost pointless. His potential love interest is cool. She is pretty much just like him but is hilarious at points in the show. Others aren't really important. If you can make it through just season one stay here don't go to season two. I thought this show was ruined for me after the last episode but then I watched the OVAs but and that was tough because it ruined me emotionally but then season two came along and just ruined the show entirely for me. All in all Darker than black was pretty good it had it's ups and it's really down low points in the anime but it is defiantly worth checking out.

Story - The plot is really quite incomprehensible. Gates, contractors and dolls are never adequately explained. They never explained WHY they wanted to get rid of the contractors, some of whom are under their employment. Hei somehow magically learns to use his sister's ability to alter matter on a quantum level at the very last minute and changes all antigate particles into gate particles, thus saving all contractors from genocide. There seemed to be some kind of overarching theme in this series that can be only described as "people with superpowers are still people!" which seemed rather bizarre and irrelevant to just about everything. 
Art- The art is amazing as expected from Bones. The series is very well animated and does not skimp on action scenes, which have excellent choreography although are relatively short compared to some shounen series. The character designs are excellent. 


Sound - Not great considering it's Yoko Kanno who has done some great pieces in the past. The jazzy music fits neither the action nor the talking scenes. Track 24 is possibly the only one that captures the mood of the series. 


Character - The characters are not exactly cardboard cutouts but neither are they very well fleshed out. For starters, we almost never see Hei truly relaxed. He always wore a "nice guy" persona whenever he wasn't wearing the white mask of doom. The same is true for most other major characters in the series. Minor characters such as Havoc and Shihoko are developed fairly well for two episodes, where they're relaxed and spill out their true thoughts, and then they're killed off and have no bearing on the story ever again. It's quite frustrating to invest two entire episodes in a quite likeable character only to see them killed off for the rest of the series, especially when the main characters were developed nowhere to the extent as these one-shot characters were. 


Enjoyment - I thoroughly enjoyed this series, even though I couldn't relate to any of the characters and I thought the superpowers were really badly used. I especially enjoyed watching the development of characters like Havoc and Shihoko, which made me feel frustrated when they were killed at the end of their two-episode arcs. 


Overall - Very enjoyable even with all its flaws in character development, story and sound.

But there are times when it's really fun, mainly Hei swinging around on ropes knifing and shocking the shit out of people. Beyond that, don't expect much.
