Slade’s Quick Review
“When I say badass you say Hei!” “Badass!” “ hi hello….” “No I said Hei…” “yes hello”. So, this is the story of cool man McCool and his adventures of being a BAMF. In a world of superhumans it is hard to truly know who is the strongest, and the main characters powers definitely don’t compete, that is why he is awesome. He is an assassin who is constantly against people with greater gifts then he, but he always manages to succeed. The main character goes through a lot of internal conflict which the show only subtlety shows, but feel this adds alot for a show which often has small dialogue overall. The feel of "cool" is emphasized by the music which rivals that of bleach and death note. Now this review only speaks for the first season…in the second season he gets burdened by a horrible supporting character and they got rid of all the good ones. So just pretend the second season doesn’t exist also just like death note. So if you want to watch an anime that gives you those "This is awesome" vibes then I highly recommend this show.

The story is overall pretty good but it won't leave you wanting more. As you watch throughout the series, it's just about completing the whole thing. It's pretty decent, though. There's heartfelt moments in here and there, there's comedy in some of the episodes, and don't forget all these random female characters secretly have a crush on your average mysterious but nice guy who pretends to be a student although not once we ever see this guy study throughout the whole series lol. He randomly get into jobs where there's a case or incident because he supposed to have missions ( well he does ).


I honestly think that the main issue with this series would be that they don't provide us enough background information of the characters. And despite the characters showing interesting powers and motifs for what they do throughout the series, nothing happened in the series that makes you really into any of the character enough. It's just like, "Oh, character A did that, sick moves! Ok. moving on.... anyway..... " 


It's just kind of dull, but anyway quite entertaining. I honestly don't consider it awful, it's just that it has a good potential to be more, but it's just gets dull.

You really have to watch and pay attention closely to understand this story to the full. Although the first few episodes weren't captivating, afterwards you'll understand more about the ability of contractors. Only towards the middle/end will you learn about the protagonist and his background and how it will effect the future. I'm not the biggest fan of slow beginnings, but the more you watch the anime, the more you'll understand, and that will give you a reason to binge watch in one night;)

My first review!
Darker Than Black is one of the classics IMO and will always be one of my favourites. It may be a bit difficult at first to get into but it is completely worth it!! If you're into dark atmospheres, interesting story lines, give this one a shot; you'll love it!!
Story: 8
First, the story. I gave it an eight because the plot was exciting and riddled with plot-twists but still managed to fit the anime's previously-mentioned atmosphere. It is about these superhumans called Contractors, each one with a special type of ability for which s/he must pay a price, sometimes even with their bodiesor health or even lives at risk. It was made for an incredible manga/anime, which DTB definitely is! But then again, I didn't give it a 10 because personally, I didn't think the story was unfolded properly to be easily understood, so for the first few episodes I found it a bit difficult to follow up without a few guidelines. Also because I hated how they introduced amazing characters with interesting backstories and personalities, and killed them off or got rid of them in the same or the next episode. Oh well, maybe it's just me. Not gonna criticise the fanservice because a) it wasn't too heavy and the characters didn't have to do anything far out of place IIRC to show it.)


Art: 9

I loved the animation, it was different from most anime I saw and I found it great, amazing actually!! Keep in mind that it wasn't produced in this decade, but it still delivered for amazing action scenes and excellent backgrounds and looks overall.


Sound: 10

I easily gave it a perfect ten because nothing was wrong with the voice-acting, it was simply amazing. Moreover, its opening/ending soundtracks easily made one of the best collections. They chose great bands for great songs. I found the background music to be so good and fitting for every scene it was used in, whether it was sad, exciting, suspenseful, comedic, anything!


Character: 10

The different powers, personalities, remuneration methods, and the syndicate/contractor/doll variations are all very big important elements of this category. Let's start with the main character: Hei, a contractor who outside his job acts as a transfer student named Li Shunsheng, from China. Since he's not a real contractor, he is able to have emotions much like humans and a could-be-called-complex personality, he's likely to judge any situation he's put in through both logic AND emotion, unlike the usual contractors who can only do so through logic. This is such an interesting addition to the story. The other main characters and supporting ones are also great, with intriguing backstories and without noticing I became very curious as to know how each character that's a doll or contractor came to be that way. Overall, awesome characters that are sure to have you hooked.


Enjoyment: 7

The confusion was a bit too much for me, so it was hard to watch at first (as I've mentioned earlier) but when I got further into it, I couldn't stop. It was incredible.


Overall: 10

Overall..... Outstanding.


Hope my review was helpful.

This is a review of both seasons of Darker than Black, by the way.
Let's discuss Bones Studio. I have seen Fullmetal Alchemist, Soul Eater, and FMA: Brotherhood before this, and I liked them all a lot. The same goes for Darker than Black. If I had to choose a show that this reminds me of, it would be the second half or Fullmetal Alchemist. They have the gritty tone, the philosophy, and similar character moments. This makes sense; both the second half of Fullmetal Alchemist and Darker than Black are original works by Bones. Darker than Black is, like, part supernatural, part psychological thriller, partnoir. In it are plenty of decent characters, great artistic writing moments, and a thoughtful commentary on what it truly means to be human. This is a very good combination of action show and philosophical art piece. The dub by Funimation is also pretty impressive. Jason Liebrecht, John Swasey, Alison Viktorin, and Kate Oxley all do good jobs. I would highly recommend checking this show out. Darker than Black gave other original works by Bones like Wolf's Rain and RahXephon higher priority on my Plan To Watch list.

First and foremost I have absolutely no idea what the title has to do with actual plot of the show. That said it didn't interfere with my overall enjoyment or ability to watch it. 
Story: 
Essentially taking the idea of assassins with superpowers going from there the plot of Darker Than Black is fairly interesting. Contractors, as they are referred to in the series, are the power wielding assassins working for a mysterious organization known as the Syndicate. As these contractors become more of a problem the Japanese police force assigns a special unit to investigate them. 
This show requires a lot of patience asthe pacing in the beginning is a bit slow and raises more questions than it answers. For example the first good chunk of the show deviates from the bigger arc and follows a standard "opponent of the week" formula. It isn't until well into the back half of the series that the main arc picks up again and questions are getting answered. That said I still found the side stories fairly compelling. They also involve at least one of the main characters to some degree. Which prevents these side arcs from becoming meaningless filler. 



Art: 

BONES is a studio known for producing some really beautiful animation. Depending on the animation director you may notice similarities in character designs among the various shows they have worked on. In the case of Darker Than Black, I believe the character designs were done by Takahiro Komori, and based on original designs Yuji Iwahara who is best known for his work on King of Thorn. The art style overall fits the show. The character designs are simple but not so much they turn into blobs once they're in the background. Speaking of backgrounds both scenes of Heaven and Hell's gate were absolutely stunning in my opinion. I also must give credit to the action sequences. They utilize a variety of angles and perspectives, creating suspense at the right moments. 


Sound: 


MUSIC:

The music and soundtrack was composed by Yoko Kanno, who composed the music for shows like Cowboy Bebop. So right there that should give a hint to the quality of this soundtrack. The opening theme for the first half of the series is  "Howling" by Abingdon Boys School, and the ending theme, "Tsukiakari" (ツキアカリ?, lit. "Moonlight") by Rie fu. Both of which I found extremely catchy. In fact everytime I hear "Tsukiakari" it becomes stuck in my head for about three days. The second half of the series uses "Kakusei Heroism (The Hero Without a "Name")" by An Cafe and "Dreams" by High and Mighty Color for the opening and ending themes respectively. The background scores fit their scenes and help carry the story along. 


AUDIO:

I have only seen bits and pieces of the original Japanese so I can't really provide much commentary on that as I don't have much to work with. The english dub is done by Funimation, a company known for producing quality dubs. Jason Liebrecht is absolutely perfect as both mild mannered exchange student Li Shenshun and Hei. He is able to move from one vocal range to another without sounding forced and allowing the two characters to remain more or less separate from each other. Also points to John Swasey who voices Huang. Swasey being another actor known for their diverse range. Finally MAJOR bonus points to Kate Oxley who voices Section-4 Chief, Misaki Kirihara. Prior to this show Oxley, being fairly new, was best known for her role as Momo Adachi in the shoujo anime Peach Girl. Kirihara being her first serious role, she absolutely nailed it. She was able to convey a serious tone without sounding too robotic and shy away from sounding too girly or young. Safe to say her performance here is most likely what lead to her being cast in Psycho Pass. Finally Brina Palencia is able to convey the necessary robotic tone of Yin without sounding monotonous and boring. 


Characters:

Here's where the show's biggest weakness lies. The overall development of the characters is slightly inconsistent. The main character Hei isn't really given much backstory until MUCH later into the show and to certain extent the second season. He also has a tendency to float in and out of the story and randomly show up at the end of certain episodes regardless of his role in that episode's story. The other two main characters, Yin and Huang are given slightly more detail in their respective episodes than Hei is in the entire series. Even some of the supposed bad guys get more background info and many of them end up redshirts anyway lasting maybe an episode or two. This was all somewhat of an issue for me because I really wanted to know more about Hei and the Syndicate. Being what I assume is the somewhat anti-hero we're supposed to route for, I wanna be able to route for him! But it's difficult to do that when he's given little backstory and barely in the show for a good portion of the time. 


Overall Enjoyment: 

Despite it's flaws I really do like this show. In fact I own both seasons on DVD.  On the upside the animation, music, and voice acting are all 100% solid. The overall concept is interesting enough on its own. On the downside the plot is extremely slow and poses more questions than it answers. And the ones that do get answered are not up until the very end. Character development is inconsistent as some major characters are given very little backstory and some minor characters are given more despite lasting a very short amount of time. I still consider this show a classic and it does have a special place in my heart mainly because at the time I watched it there really wasn't anything else like it to compare it to. 


Recommendation: 

If you're deciding upon watching it or not, I would recommend streaming it (legally!) first, form your own ideas about it and going from there. That said if you're a sci-fi fan including supernatural powers and mystery I say give this a shot.

Darker Than Black. What originally got me into the series was many people I knew speaking about it, which finally made me want to look into the series, and I'm glad I did.
The story behind Darker than Black is based on a world where people with supernatural abilities known as Contractors exist, and how much life has changed due to their presence, organizations from around the world, ranging from the CIA to the MI-6 of Britain are competing for power, using Contractors to gain power. The story itself is interesting, and over the course of it you really grow fond of the characters, much ofthem being memorable, even side characters ranging from a crack pot, chain-smoking detective to an twisted man who uses his blood as a weapon.\n\n
The art and sound worked well for the series; I found the art style to be very good, and overall enjoyed the series a lot.

I have seen Darker Than Black (DTB) soo many times - ultimately because I love it. But my consistent return to the series has allowed me to deconstruct it, so let me continue wholeheartedly unbiased.
Firstly, what I think makes me watch it over and over again, is the significant character development that flows evenly over the episodes.
Normally I hate the episodic 'to each episode his own' presentation of storyline (i.e. Jigoku Shoujo), but DTB seems to take this in it's stride. Showing the narrative through other's eyes and experiences - as well as the main characters in rarity - allows new content to constantly engageus, adding an apt authenticity to the mix as the natural progression of events and characters are showcased in a very organic fashion.

The dramatic irony of keeping the main characters out of the bigger picture also lengthens the charm, resulting in a mystery, unravelled unwittingly by the audience at their own pace.

Every character transforms in this anime. I mean EVERY character. Whether it is the slow realisation of fate, or the quick yet influential paradigm shift between one episode and the next (a la Kenji's ball growing), adaptation is vital to the survival of dramatic veracity and cohesion of DTB.



The art is another praise to the series. The neo-noir feel paints the city in palettes of browns, greens and purples, which is cleverly reflected in the costume of the Black Reaper. The characters are distinct, with their own tells and quirks, unique enough to stand on their own, but similar enough to synthesis a conglomerate of functional characters. I did however find myself wishing that the nationality of the characters was made more distinct (with the risk of stereotypes and racism it might have been good to avoid it) as I didn't even know Hei was Chinese til I googled it! That being said, Alice Wang/Wei were tastefully true to their culture, the ChiPao relevant, and I definitely appreciated that.

The action takes the cake in this anime. It is so artful, engaging, creative, and fluid. Hei has a definite style, and this remains throughout. The opening always had me cheering, the snipets of fighting and art outstanding.



The music was great, I found myself singing along to the themes (in Japanese, imagine my surprise), and the digetic sounds certainly sustained the tension and engagement.


What I didn't like (it may seem unfair and anal) was the cheap narrative method to establish the situation - inner monologue explaining what has been consistent for years, whaaat, lack of background/orientation of the South American war, the overuse of deathstares, hit and miss comedy of Mao, Hei's sudden love for Yin, and the constant breaking of the "Contractors have no feelings" rule that we are reminded of incremently. The real detriment is the dialogue because of story purposes, rather than dialogue because that is how the Characters are likely to act.



This is getting long-winded. Obviously I thoroughly enjoyed this season (I don't ever want to think about the second again!), even though it is generally not the genre I would pursue, my gamble paid off; and hopefully so will/did yours. I definitely recommend watching Darker Than Black: Kuro no Keiyakusha, because on first glimpse, it is certainly flawless.

Story: 7/10
 	There are two gates, one appeared in South America a decade ago, and the other Hell’s gate has appeared in Japan along with a group of beings known as contractors who made sort of deal with the devil in order to gain superhuman powers, in turn turning them into government killing machines for the most part. It then follows a group of contractors controlled by the syndicate detailing their escapades and shenanigans . The plot isn’t really straightforward at all and it takes a really long time to figure out what's happening and what are the motivations to most of the main character'sactions. It starts off as a sort of monster of the week episodic show where they take down various different contractors. Most of the stories involve hei and his group of allies, but the show isn't consistent at all quality wise, and the only times I really like the show is when Gai Kurasawa and Kiko Kayanuma are involved in the plot.


Characters: 8/10


 	The main character is the “Black Reaper” Hei, who is a contractor who is Badass fighting contractors at night, and Lee a hardworking and glutinous citizen at day. Most of the main characters are contractors who don’t feel any human emotions and are therefore extremely reasonable, and that’s a problem. While they are able to pull off extravagant stunts due to this they are also pretty hard to relate to when they don't reveal/have any human emotions. Due to how large the cast is there isn;t too many characters that is developed significantly, so it's funny that my two favorite characters have little to no character development with Gai Kurasawa or Kiko Kayanuma. Kiko Kayanuma is joy to watch because of her carefree spirit, her confidence, and her huge passion for anime/manga and other weebish activities


Animation/ Art Style: 7/10


 	The action scenes are well done, and some of the contractors powers are blast to watch, especially the one where he can draw his own blood, than make any surface the blood is touching vanish into thin air. The show looks pretty good, with how dark and retro the city skyline and skyscrapers look. Overall, well done and fitting for the series title. 


Sound: 6/10


 	The Opening while I enjoy Japanese rock music feels a bit too edgy for me, or that it at least feels like it's trying really hard to be edgy and cool. Which also fits with shows name. I mean what's cooler or edgier than a color darker than black. The second opening is bit of a step down in the music department and in memorability but the animation and pacing of the opening is a bit better in my opinion.


Enjoyment: 7/10


	I thought that the series was okay until around episode 17 then it was pretty good/ great till it finished. The main problem was that the characters were developed enough until the end, plus there was not enough of Gai and Kiko in the show as a whole. Still even though I have mostly stated negative statements in this review, I believe that Darker Than Black is still a fun show overall, and that it is worth the watch, the it starts off slow for a while and doesn't really pick up a lot of stem until it's nearly over. I feel like if the plot was structured differently and if we learned about some of the character backstory and reasonings sooner rather than later then we would have been able to grow a stronger connection with the main characters strengthening our attachment to them and to the show in general. Darker Than Black is a show with a quite a bit of potential that could be hopefully expanded upon with better new material.

Being a fervent BONES fan, I greatly enjoyed Dark than BLACK. But I seriously admit that I often had no idea what the hell they were talking about with the gate and stuff. The reason I liked Darker than BLACK so much was because it had a lot of style. And I like style! Not to mention Hei was an interesting character who also had style!! A very good anime. The fighting scenes had great choreography, and I just wish it had more action scenes. Intense storyline too. Since it's only 25 episodes, I recommend people give it a watch and see for themselves.

In retrospect, and because I seemingly have an incurable urge to compare things, Darker than BLACK is reminiscent of a grimmer, anime version of Wild Cards (the books). While there are no superheroics, and even contractors (the super powered characters) are relatively rare, the sheer range of the various powers as well as the odd remuneration that their use demands reminds me conceptually of the jokers from Wild Cards. While on the surface Darker than BLACK is a grim action series it also examines some fairly complex issues, such as what exactly it means to be human. But it does so without the heavy handednessor the awkward self consciousness that other similar shows have exhibited.\n\n
The main characters in Darker than BLACK are also extremely well realised and believable, while not all of them are likeable, nearly all of them are entertaining to watch. Also for those interested in such things the world that Darker than BLACK presents would be eminently playable as an rpg setting and should I chose to run non-traditional supers at some point in the future I would be sorely tempted to use the setting presented here (possibly seasoned with some material from Kaze no Stigma).

When you watche the first episode of that anime, you know nothing. And it won't change so fast like in shounens, when everyone tells you everything. You have to slowly understand the hole thing, but don't worry, it doesn't mean that the plot moves slowly. there are a lot of things that happens suddenly, like in a real life.
The main characters are dark(ptf, pretty obvious, if you have read the title) and don't seem to fully trust anyone. The whole series are brutal and real, so you can think "hopefully, my life isn't so bad as their".
The things as you see, aren't the real ones.Full of secrets and mysterious, it's darker than black.

Darker than black is one of those  anmies  , you  hear people  raving and  raving  and raving   about and in this case they happen to  be  100% right. It does indeed  live up to the hype. 
At heart , its a ' le femme nikita ' type of story and it captures the mood and the characters  perfectly.The story  writing  is intelligent  and insightful , with  exquisite  pacing and timing.
The character  development is first class , as the series progress  more and more of the layersand levels of their  stories (and the plot in general)   are revealed 


The voice acting both Japanese and English were superb. I don't remember the last  time ,I    have  heard  voice actors in English  who were so spot on perfect for their roles. Not  one  can i fault.


The art was excellent, whilst  not groundbreaking or totally  new  , it did indeed do the  job.


Enjoyment - yes  i did , both the happy moments  and  the many bittersweet or just plain  sad ones as well. The action  is  kick ass.


The  "cat"  Mao  was  just  so well voiced  by  kent williams   and John Swaseys  performance of  Huang  , was  just so good that I would  just listen to the dubbed version, just to hear those two.


Another  must  see  anmie.


ps. Haven't  yet seen the  second series or  manga , so  i  cant comment.

Darker than Black reminds me of the cartoons I use to watch as a kid, like batman beyond, static shock, and teen titans. It is an episodic anime based on a hero (anti hero in this case) who dose various missions each episode that loosely ties into the premiss of the show. The story of Darker then Black is actually pretty interesting and it would of got a 10 if there was actually a plot. However theres not and the story just gives background information and explanations for the missions. Most of the characters in this series are pretty bland or pretty generic. The maincharacter Hei is interesting however his personality isn't really defined and he comes of usually pretty dull. Some interesting characters are introduced like November 11 and the detective but they become side characters that only appear in a few episodes. The show has some good action scenes however fighting is not as prevalent as you would expect from this type of anime. The art and animation is well done and the anime features one of my favorite openings. This anime is decent and i suggest action fans to watch it if they have time. Because the show is fairly episodic with mini arcs lasting no longer then 2 episodes it is a show that you can pick up and put down fairly easily. It will not make you insane to see what will happen next. Its a slow pass anime that you can watch at your own pace. It is not one of the best or most exciting amines I have ever seen and it is highly overrated however it is not a bad show and if you have some spare time I suggest you check it out.

DaikiClub Bro Time-Saver Review:
BLUF: Darker than Black is, in one word, fun. I enjoyed it and you will too if you like action. It does fall short in character development and plot though. 8/10
Story- There was a story? Just kidding. But seirously the story is the main problem I have with this show. The first 20 (of 25) of the episodes are mostly episodic with a few plot points sprinkled in. The first half of the anime is basically villain of the week. Eventually the story does come, but it isn't that great. It makes sense and I liked the climax and resolution, the problemwas that it just ended. I thought there had to be another episode, but there was just a really stupid OVA (episode 26). 6


Art- It looks pretty good. The action scenes are great and it visually sets the tone for the show. I liked it, but it honestly isn't anything unique or special. It's Bones, you know what it's going to look like. 7


Sound (dub)- This show has an amazing OP 1. I would've said the sound was just ok, but that opening was straight fire and made it sound track memorable. There wasn't really any problems with it either. The dub voices all fit their characters pretty well and I liked the dub. Sometimes the characters lacked inflection, but I think that was just the nature of the role. 8


Characters- This show did a terrible job explaining the character motives for 12 episodes. Like I said earlier, it was just villain of the week, but then BAM! The character backstories are revealed and they're pretty good honestly. I think the secrecy of motives and backstory was intentional because the contractors and dolls are so private and secretive. I really liked the characters and thought they were all unique and fun to watch, even if they barely developed. 9


Enjoyment- I watched this show at the perfect time. It's just light enough to keep you enjoying the action, but still had emotional depth. I was coming off Erased and Ajin, so this felt great to watch. It was a lot of fun. I enjoyed every episode and would definitely recommend it to any anime veteran or beginner. 10


TL;DR- You (and I) are 9 years late, but this is a gem of a show. Watch it and enjoy.

Darker than Black is basically about a world where there are humans with special powers called Contractors, because after using their powers they have to pay a price.There is plenty of fighting scenes, so if you like to see people fight with special powers you should like this anime. not only that there isn't a lot of sub-plots so the whole 25 episodes are basically about the main story line. So give it a try and enjoy.
Story: Darker than Black is about a world where two mysterious gates appeared, called Heaven's Gate and Hell's Gate. Along with the emergence of these two places people calledcontractors appeared. Contractors are people with powers from an unknown origin, but have to pay a price for using their power, hence the name Contractors. The price can be anything from smoking a cigarette to self mutilation. Along with the Contractors are a whole night sky filled with new stars, each star representing a contractor, so when a Contractor dies a star falls. Now in this society, Contractors are kept as a secret by all governments, and at the same time used to hunt each other down, since Contractors are mainly concerned with their own survival.  Now the story might at first be somewhat confusing but it starts to makes more sense later on. It is rather quite fast and there isn't much sub-plot. There are plenty of action and fight scenes. After the first few episodes the story line is a lot easier to follow, so don't get stumped after watching like the first 3 episodes.


Art: The story mainly takes place in a heavy populated city. The artwork of the background is pretty good. The artwork of the characters are rather nice, the fighting between characters seem somewhat believable, but there are some moments where it just seem like impossible.


Sound: The sound is good, the soundtrack, especially the opening theme definitively fits the tone of the story. 


Characters: The story mainly focus on Hei, the Black Reaper. He starts of being a really cold hearted like person then slowly opens up. Which is really strange for a Contractor, even causing many Contractors to doubt whether if he was a real Contractor. The anime does have episodes that helps give more background information of each character, but again, it still ties along with the plot, so there is almost no stopping on the plot.


Enjoyment: Overall I really enjoyed this anime. It was really good, the action was great and there wasn't so much blood and gore as I expected. The story line was quite great, I thought that it was well developed and pose a great scenario about that question "What if there were humans with powers? How would they be treated?" I thought it was quite interesting, it resembles the X-Men type of human with powers but can't be seen thing. But I thought it was way better than X-men. Then ending was quite interesting though, I had to watch it twice to kind of understand about what happened. Well give this anime a shot! Hope you enjoy it!

Sigh. I guess I expected way too much from this series. It is the first series that I have watched where I felt like it was wasted potential. There were so many things and so many directions it could have gone to have made it a better story and more enjoyable to watch.
The first thing I have to point out because it's been on my mind from the beginning to the very end of watching this first season on a 2 day span. Pizza Hut. I can't stop thinking about it. There were signs everywhere. Would I have enjoyed the show more if I atefrom Pizza Hut? Possibly. I don;t know and I guess I'll never find out. If anyone knows if it's more enjoyable that way, please don't hesitate to inform me.


This anime can get interesting at times it can intrigue you, in fact if you stick it through, I

m sure you will. I'm such your curiosity will allow you to wonder and to ask lots of questions. But you know what? "F**k you!" said this anime to it's audience, "I won't answer any of your questions." Followed by a, "You will watch what I show you and you and there's nothing you can do about."


SO many of my questions have still been unanswered. Nearing the end when the contractor were fighting the humans, I saw so much abilities and potential usage of said characters and abilities that it could have been way better. Honestly I don;t know why this anime got such a high rating on MAL. I'm not the kind of person to judge an anime so harshly. Yeah this feels harsh to me, and I was entertained a very few amount of times so i wont disregard that.. BUT... this just goes to show that darn... well I guess it must be a regional thing for it to have gotten such a high ranking. Since I've already watched the first season and since I like to follow things through to the end, I will be watching the sequels as well.. I hope it gets better though.


Overall 6/10... it's fine.

First of all I'd like to point out that this anime is better suited for the adult (and mature) audience rather than for children. Also if you are looking for an anime to relax and have a good laugh or enjoy some major fisting pumping, gun slinging action this is definitely not for you either.
That said I thoroughly enjoyed this anime. It has a great plot and I liked how everything built up and set into place. Admittedly there were a few loose ends which weren't covered properly. The character were built quite well and voice acting was good too. Although I did say thiswasn't for those looking "fisting pumping, gun slinging action" it doesn't mean there wasn't any action. 


The fight and action sequences complemented the storyline really well. In my opinion they had the perfect amount of action for a series of this nature.


I'd recommend this to anyone who loves series with great plot build ups and if you are the type of person who enjoys series with a deeper meaning behind it than that apparent this is definitely for you!

Darker than Black involves these characters that are called contractors that each have there own special ability(exempli gratia electricity). These contractors fight against the main character who is also a contractor. 
Story:
Story consists of basically 2 episode story arcs. Each story introduces a villain that has his own unique power and the main characters have to stop him usually. Most of the arcs are interesting while some are boring. 
Art:
Majority of the show takes place at night. The animators did a pretty good job and transcribing a dark, brooding atmosphere. However the animation will rarely wow you like a show like mob psycho 100 will.


Sound:

There are 2 openings which both sound absolutely amazing. The soundtrack is also solid. 


Characters:

The characters are what make this show great. The show consists of 4 characters that have to work together to get shit done. The protagonist is a straight up badass and one of the best main characters in Anime. He is a stoic killer with little regard for his opponents life. Another character is a black cat which that always a smarmy, fitting joke at the ready. The 3rd one is New Yorker that has a heart of gold. Finally theres a girl that is emotionless and barely talks but makes up for it with her cool abilities. 



My main gripe with the show is the same as Cowboy Beboop. Each episode has very little buildup towards the finish making the ending of the show very lackluster. This is the only thing keeping the show from being a masterpiece.


Still a very good show 8/10

After watching DTB for the third time, I decided that it was time to write a review for a series that I feel is pretty underrated. Since this is my first time writing a review, I'll keep it simple.
PROS
Characters. Both main and side characters are a real pleasure to watch, complete with their own back stories and this helps viewers connect with them more. As you progress through the story, characters that you might have initially disliked will turn into ones that you can actually empathize with, or maybe even start to like.
Plot. While the basic plot itself is pretty standard stuff (dystiopian future, specialabilities, unknown forces, etc.), the side plots and little twists and turns are what make DTB a true pleasure to watch. Aside from the final few episodes, the first two halves of the series are divided into mini arcs which usually consists of 2 -3 parts. That doesn't mean the finale itself is not a good watch, for it is certainly an interesting finale to the series.


Artwork. The scenes are really well drawn, and the atmosphere surrounding each episode suits the tone quite perfectly. Action scenes do not disappoint and are hugely entertaining.


Music. I found the music very suitable for the tone of the show as well. Comical, dark, soothing, nostalgic, melancholic. The composer did a fantastic job.


CONS


The main issue I have with the series also involves its greatest strength, the characters. I found a few of the side and main characters lacking when it came to development, as if they used simply to evolve the plot, or to help the viewers gain insight into the overall story. 


OVERALL. A great series to watch, with extremely intriguing characters that serve to strengthen what was a pretty basic overall plot. But then again, how many original plots can we come up with until we run out of ideas, right? Definitely worth a watch.

Having just finished this series, coupled with my inability to fall asleep… here’s a quick review.
Darker Than Black follows the story of Hei, a contractor. A contractor is essntially a mutant. Humanlike in appearance, but with abilities. Abilities that range from gravity manipulation, to being able to make blood explode with a click of your fingers. Obscure, I know. Anyway, I won’t provide a detailed synopsis, as that can easily be done by a quick Google search.
However, to give an understanding of what the series is about and whether you’d like it… I’ll sum it up like this: Think the blockbuster sci-fi Inception… Now, thinkX-MEN. If these two series got together, in a hotel room… with some Barry White and scented candles in the background… the outcome, 9 months later, would be Darker Than Black.


I have watched the first series; which is 25 episodes long. The second series is now also out. And it is good, no doubt. There are many things it does superbly. The animation is crisp, high quality and vivid. The music is powerful and compliments the scenes perfectly, whether it is adrenaline fuelled fight scenes, or the more emotional ones. The characters too, are for the most part original and interesting. T


However, and this is a big however, DTB falls down on the key areas for me. The story is at times too slow paced and you feel like saying “Okay, stop talking for 15 minutes and actually do stuff!” Aside from that, the information is at times too hard to follow. I found myself confused in several parts as to what was going on, who certain characters were, and why they were doing what they were doing. In the end, I found myself watching the last couple of episodes just to finish the series rather than becaus I really wanted to see what happened next.


Overall, a solid sci-fi anime. If you like X-Men and Inception, you’ll probably like this. It is also quite a grown up anime, there are comedy and silly parts in it on occasion, but it is quite a mature series.


All in all, from me, Darker Than Black gets a 7/10.

The story line in Darker than Black is nothing less than exceptional. I never knew exactly what was going to happen next and was always on the edge of my seat waiting to figure things out, despite the impossible struggle of understanding until the story was good an ready for me to. Even when I started watching this beautiful creation the second time, my experience was similar. Of course I knew what was up the second time around, but the excitement and emotional highs that the anime gave me were the same. To be honest, story lines aren't really unique anymore, but Darker than Blacktook its genre and put a real twist to it and I have yet to find anything really similar. It is truly an amazing anime and most likely my favorite.


The artwork is really good too! If you are the type of person that only likes shoujo art though, this might not be for you. It does have a more shounen flavour to it. I on the other hand think that as long as they don't look like blobs then it is probably fine. The artwork is clear and really consistent and overall I just think that it matches the story and colours the story quite well.


Now, I'm not sure what it means by sound but if we are talking OST's, sound effects, or even the voice actors themselves. I think that this anime is excellent in that. Whether watching the English dub or watching it subbed, I have done both as at the time I first watched it the second season was not dubbed yet, I think that anyone can agree that the voices really match the characters well! I do prefer the dubbed version in this case, but the voice actors do an exceptional job with the characters. They sound real and alive, just like it was the actor themselves on the screen, it is brilliant. The music track of the anime also is really great.


As for the characters, I couldn't possibly say enough about them. Hei is actually the most in depth character I have ever seen. He is such a multi-layered character that I really can't get enough of him.Yin is another excellent character with many sides! Overall, I found that all the characters were rather in depth and complicated and rather than hinder the experience of the anime, it just made it that much more amazing.


By now I think it is obvious that I thoroughly enjoyed this anime. I watched it several years ago, but like I said, have started to rewatch it, that is how amazing it is. If you knew me, you would know rewatching is not a think I do. However, whenever I talk about this anime I get incredibly excited. Sometimes I cry. The story is just so moving and brilliant that I can't help feeling a personal connection to the characters.


This is a beautiful anime! Even if you don't think you are an action person please watch! The story is so much deeper than that and there are many other genres that are very important to the plot! It is an anime that can really be enjoyed by anyone!

Story-7: the story is fairly simple. A group of 'contractors' get introduced to the world when an area called 'hell's gate' appears in Tokyo. Contractors are people with certain powers who work for 'syndicate's'(that's all I'm going to say). The story follows one contractor called 'Hei' who works for a syndicate, every episode shows Hei performing a task for the syndicate he works for which usually last around 2 episodes. All in all, the story was simple but very well done.
Art-8: the art in DTB looks unique and amazing. All of the character designs are out of this world and the background's and the wayeverything is drawn looks gorgeous. However, sometimes the animation in certain other things looked off at times, although this wasn't an issue.


Sound-10: honestly, what else can you expect from yoko kanno? An absolutely beautiful soundtrack with every song working effectively in the scene it was played. Both of the opening themes are also some of the best I've seen.


Character-7: overall, the characters in DTB were well done. Hei is a complete badass and you want to know more about him(although the series gives us vague snippets of his past near the end of the series), yin is just amazingly written, everyone else in hei's syndicate was also well written. Some of the other characters in my opinion were a hit and miss, including misaki who I didn't care for at all. I think that all of the contractors had Cool and intresting powers but they weren't developed enough which made me rate the characters a little lower than I should have.


Enjoyment-6: the first 14 or so episodes were fantastic. Around episode 14 explains yin's past and that is probably one of the best episodes I've ever seen in any anime ever. I'm being serious. However, the final 12 episodes were a a complete drag to get through. They were boring and predictable. You knew exactly what was going to happen, 'Hei finds contractor he has to fight, he kills them, the end'. This is what all of the final 12 episodes were about(except for the final 2 which were great). At times I found myself having to try and watch some of the final episodes and just ended up Turning it off. I don't know why I didn't like the last half as much as the first but this is just what I think.


Overall-7: is DTB worth your time? Absolutely. It is a fun and great looking series with good characters and an almost perfect soundtrack. But, the last half of the series drags far too much out. However this honestly depends on what you can stand and how patient you are with any series.

However this isn't a bad series by any means, you should definitely go out and watch it if you have the time.

I'm no super-anime-fanatic-guru, but Darker Than Black has to be one of the best shows I've seen.
Not being your average high-school supernatural story, the plot is one to remember. If you like supernatural action anime, DtB is for you. The fighting scenes are awesome, though usually fairly short. To me the series seemed a little more serious than other shows of similar genres (though DtB is rated M/R I don't really think it's that bad, there is blood and finger breaking, but I don't think it's mature material, of course it depends on your own tolerance for blood). DtB seemed to be lacking "actual" humor,as in the characters don't do or say anything exceptionally funny. But it has its moments. The characters are ones you won't forget, not to sound cliche, but by then end of the series you'll really feel for them. \n
I would defiantly recommend Darker Than Black to anyone who likes supernatural ass-kicking. \n
(I prefer the original version versus the (English) dubbed one, so if you don't mind reading subs I would encourage that you watched the Japanese version)

Despite very high ratings for this anime, I was quite disappointed with Darker Than Black. I was looking forward to something that would rival Code Geass, but it seems that I was not able to enjoy it as much as I did. 
STORY: 7/10
The story is original and interesting, however it could have been developed into a much more complex, full anime if there was more explanation and more episodes leading up to the ending. The whole thing seemed like little chapters that had little relevance to anything and the end was basically episodes 20-26. 
ART: 6/10
I have VERY high expectations for art, so thisrating is not too bad for my standards. It could have been better.\n
SOUND: 9/10\n
Pretty nice music starting from season two. I like the bgms when things start to get exciting.\n
CHARACTER: 7/10\n
I felt there was not enough character development for me to feel attached to the characters. Had there been more background story to each character I'm sure the overall story would appeal more to me.\n
ENJOYMENT: 7/10\n
I found myself bored quite a few times and skipped ahead of talking parts sometimes. It was a nice ending - a bit rushed - and the series was overall confusing. Not spectacular but not horrible.\n
OVERALL: 7/10\n
In all honesty I was disappointed with the anime since it had such high ratings and fell short to my standards. HOWEVER, I am looking forward to a much better, more fast-paced and exciting second season!

Darker than Black was a fairly pleasant anime to watch. I've heard a lot of good comming from this anime, so I've decided to give a try. I wasn't overly surprised by it. It is an original concept and a fairly good idea behind, but they never dwell enough into it. We get this world where two mysterious gates appeared who knows why and who knows how. It is never explained. Not only that. It also changes some humans into contractors, giving them abilities beyond what a normal human being can do. There is a price to pay that differs from person to person. Again,it is not really explained why that is.


Not that the idea of people with superpowers is wrong, but a good explanation is needed. The contractors are linked to the Gate and...? It stops there. As far as the payment goes, some are quite plain and some are just gruesome, like eating cigarettes or children. They do mention at some point that it could be link to a trauma the contractor went through when he was still ''human''.


Story wise, there is a lot of plot points (I mention them above) that kept me from enjoying the show as much as I would have otherwise. The two-parters episodes felt really episodic. The storyline still got across, but not enough.


Character wise, Hei was a breath of fresh air. With his two personalites, going back and forth between them, he was really well played. As for his team... Some of them had a background, others didn't. It would have been nice to know at least a little but more about Mao. You have this talking cat, and we know he has lost his original body, but how? It is never answered, or nothing that is related to him. Yin is still weird. We got her history, but how did she became a doll? Dolls are never explaned either. The backgrounds characted are nice but there is nothing much to talk about.


The animation was good, between slower/faster scene. Some of the action scenes were a nice balance of fast-pace action and slow-mo, to let us fully see what is happening. Expected nothing less from Bones. The drawings were good, but not great.


Overall, I enjoyed this serie. The story plotholes were a big thrownback.

So, I never really wanted to watch Darker Than Black, but my boyfriend kept telling me how much I would love it if I did.
Well...he was right T~T
After watching the first episode, I was completely hooked on the story and as the anime went on, I loved learning about every single character and all of their weird payments (if you haven't watched this anime, just watch it and you'll know what a payment it and find yourself picking which one you'd want).
I have not yet seen the 2nd series, but I'm planning on it. If you find yourself second guessing on whether or not towatch this, don't; JUST WATCH IT. \n\n
Lastly, the music is great too, esp the openings. Jazz and classical throughout the show? Check. Kinda reminded me of Cowboy Bebop.\n\n
Alright, stop wasting your time reading this and just hit up YouTube and watch it for free on the Funimation site.

During one ominous night, a part of Tokyo became what is known as “Hell’s Gate”, a field that seems to be closely tied to the emergence of Dolls, emotionless spiritual mediums, and Contractors, assassins with superpowers who only rely on their logic. Our main guy, Hei, is one of these Contractors, currently working for a mysterious crime organization only known as the “Syndicate”. Another thing you should know about Contractors is that after they use their powers they have to fulfill their contract by performing some specific activity, that is harmful and unpleasant to them. This element is one of my favourite things about theseries, since it really helps to distinguish it from other series where people have superpowers, and it gives the show sort of it’s own personality. 


STORY 9/10

The first 22 episodes of Darker Than Black are broken into 2 episode arcs, which is the reason I initially started to watch this series. I am a big fan of episodic shows like Mushishi or Jigoku Shoujo but Darker Than Black is a little different. All of the arcs are somehow related to the main plotline or at least reveal something interesting about one of the main characters. The last three episodes conclude the story in a truly spectacular manner that leaves you wanting more. I’ve seen some shows with mysterious premise that have a terrible ending but Darker Than Black is definitely not one of these. Another thing about the series is that it never spells out for you what is currently going on. You have to figure out a lot of it by yourself by reading in between the lines but no matter how much you try some parts of the plot will remain unknown for the whole 25 episodes, which is why I took of the one point in the story ranking. There is a sequel though so there is still hope that it will shed some light onto the mysteries of Darker Than Black.


CHARACTERS 6/10

In my opinion, characters were the weak point of this series mainly because of one thing, the main character Hei/Li/BK201/Black Reaper... I’ve seen some people who really like this guy, and I can kind of see why, but personally I think that he is the worst thing about this series. He really has two different personalities; one as an innocent transfer student who’s annoying as hell and another one as a cold-blooded killer who changes his face expression once per arc, at best. He goes through a fair bit of development but you can’t really tell that about him. Same monotone voice, same facial expression, same fighting style and even when he steps forward and does something big and unexpected it’s still more of the same. He’s not a broken character by any means; it’s just that I can’t stand him. Although the supporting cast was a little stereotypical they were well developed and most of the side characters weren’t underused.  


ART 9/10

Art is definitely another strong point of this series. It is not quite up to the likes of “5 centimeters per Second” but the animation creates a great, gloomy atmosphere that’s really at the core of the series. The abilities and the fights are animated skillfully, because even in wild and intense fights you always know what is going on and even when some of the fights aren’t that great, the animation usually makes up for it. The characters each have their unique look so you’ll never mistake them for others and even the CGIs manage to blend in quite well. 


SOUND 8/10

The first opening is kind of neat because it features lines that directly relate to the series but it also has a sequence where the opening titles appear in a way that kind of hurt my eyes, so I usually ended up skipping it. The second opening is solid but nothing captivating. Both endings are on the mellow side, but the second one is kind of odd and seems to be made for some romance/slice of life anime. The backing sound through ought the series is good and, again, helps to reinforce the atmosphere, although I am not a big fan of some of the strings-heavy classical pieces. I think some dramatic piano music would fit much better with a series like that. 


ENJOYMENT 7/10

Darker Than Black is a good series that has a good storyline with great ending. The technical aspects are also really well done, and the pacing is good too but the thing that bothered me a lot was the lead character who annoyed the hell out of me. However, I’ve seen a lot of reviews that praised the main guy so it might be just me and personal preference shouldn’t keep you away from seeing a solid series like Darker Than Black.


OVERALL 7/10

Story 9/10

Characters 6/10

Art 9/10

Sound 8/10

Enjoyment 7/10

TOTAL 39/50 = 7.8/10 


The review ratings round out to 8/10, but personally I rated it a 7 just because I don't think that it is quite as good as other animes I rated 8.


The ratings round out to an 8 but, personally, I rated it a 7 just because I don’t think it’s quite as good as other animes I rated 8.

Tread carefully through this one now. Darker than Black focuses on the existence of people called "contractors" who have obtained supernatural abilities. Hei, a contractor with abilities related to electricity, is the protagonist. His struggle seems to be finding his actual purpose in the world besides being a killing machine. The actual origin of the characters and events in the plot are explained very vaguely; I'm assuming that they lead the audience to make their own interpretations throughout the show. Because of the lack of background storytelling, Darker than Black can become a little confusing at times, but nevertheless it remains to be a classic.There's so little to explain about this series, but I believe it mostly speaks for itself. You have to watch it to understand.

"One of the easiest formulas to execute in the supernatural genre is each relevant character having a specific skill from berth. Each time we see a new character we are introduced to a new gimmicky skill set that our hero’s balanced ability has to overcome somehow. Its really handy because you only have to explain how everyone gets these abilities once and it applies for everyone. Darker then Black is one of the best examples of this formula."
Darker than black is a very solid series that’s quality degrades the closer you reach the end.The series starts out strong with good characters and a diverse setting.As the end nears the pace begins to ramp up steeply. By the end we lose sight of the characters and their motivations. Despite how well made and diverse it is, Darker than Black is a series that falls apart right when it matters most.


Darker Than Black follows your typical supernatural setting. A cataclysmal even created false stars in the sky and gave creation to supernatural beings with powers that vary greatly. Its biggest strength in this regard is its diversity. Rather then head the elemental route, Darker Than Black offers some truly unique abilities. A fat opera singer with deadly volume, a man with explosive blood, we are presented with an array of abilities that diverge far from the standard pokemon type chart style abilities. Combine this with a rich cast of interesting characters and you have the backbone for a solid B+ series.


The first fifteen episodes or so are mostly about becoming acclimated to the world. Much of what happens is to flesh out the characters that will be in play and what our hero’s motivation is. Many of these episodes are simply filler type episodes that have random side quests and world building tours. From there on the speed of events begins to quicken very hastily. Most episodes consisted of individual events or missions. The last third however is a tangled series of events that stream out at a rapid pace very dissimilar to the rest of the series.


As the climax approaches Darker Than Black introduces a new antagonist. We have no prior exposition to these people and, despite having ties to the protagonist prior to the series beginning, they feel as if they come out of nowhere. From then on there’s little time left to cover everything that is going on. By the end our protagonist is presented with a choice that comes out of nowhere and a decision that makes no sense. There is a major change in character that occurs without any foreshadowing or explanation. A switch gets flipped and everything is changed. Then it ends.


Darker then black confused the crap out of me. Everything was very manageable and controlled. Then a green haired chick appears and Hei stops acting like himself. We never get a complete explanation of what happened. The next series jumps ahead multiple years to a completely broken Hei. Did we witness the shattering of his character or what? What happened to Hei was framed as a breakthrough of enlightenment but when you step back it makes zero sense and leaves the ending to Darker Than Black in shambles. This series could have been much better has it take the time to explain itself.

Darker than Black was an anime that has quite an interesting plot at the begging. Its a real mystery and keeps you coming back for more. There is a well array of action based drama and character narration. Certain things happen throughout this anime that make say "man what the hell happened before all this started". Its a true demonstration of a mystery. The characters are quite interesting as well as their super human abilities go. Its fun to see how the main character deals with his foes. He has a unique style and personality As the story unravels you really become attached to itand just have to see how it all pans out. I fell like there could have been better reasoning for certain things in the anime and a stronger more defined "force of opposition" i suppose but in the end this anime wasn't about heroes. It was more so about the characters finding closure within themselves and thus a better understanding of the people they live amongst, which aren't always human. I say this anime is definitely worth the watch and there is actually a 2nd season on its way too so if you do enjoy Darker than Black youll have something to look forward to.

Darker Than Black- Overall Summary (No Elaboration on Story).
- What a journey! Darker Than Black (first season anyway) is just a must watch anime for those of you looking for a no bullshit anime. However, if you are looking for tits and fan-service galore, than I implore you to watch something of a severely lower quality such as HOTD. If you are familiar with Cowboy Bebop and enjoyed it, chances are you will enjoy Darker Than Black.
-The story is mostly, episodic , but does follow an overall story in the background, which becomes a lot more apparent in the later episodes. Although, the show willleave you in the moment that you long for more, it might be better for those of you who do not want confusion to stay clear of latter seasons. As the conclusion, in the first season is well reached. But  I myself, did not heed to this warning given to me by other fans of the series, the later series are watched at the cost of severe decrease in writing and character development.\n\n
But just WATCH THE SERIES! Most of you, who watch anime not for the tits and panty shots will not regret it!

Note: This includes a review for the Second season and Gaiden OVA as well
Bones does a fantastic job with the Darker Than Black series in creating a dark fantasy world where humans and "contractors" with supernatural powers are at odds with each other over not just control/power but also the right to exist. The MC, Hei, is so intriguing with his constant struggle between his human and contractor side (not to mention that he is a complete badass). The rest of the crew including Yin, Mao and even Huang make a very dynamic team and each has a very dark and complicated past. Even theother supporting characters get fleshed out pretty well.


The first season is an absolute thrill and I couldn't stop watching till the very end. It does a great job of having individual arcs (that are each 2 episodes long) which introduce us to tons of great characters while slowly delving into the deep and satisfying overarching story. There's a ton of plot twists and you honestly don't know where everyone's true intentions and motivations lie. The quality is great throughout and the action and anticipation keeps on building until the very last episode. However, the second season (Gemini) and OVA (Gaiden) are definitely not as strong as the first season (I mean it's a tough act to follow) but are still enjoyable nonetheless even with their flaws. Particularly, I just wish that Hei was a bit more of the focus in the second season rather than Suo. Also, the season 2 ending...


The action is awesome throughout the entire series and you see a good variety of different powers amongst the many contractors that we meet in this series. You can tell Hei is a badass but he isn't super over-powered compared to the enemies which makes the battles more entertaining. The dub is pretty solid for this series with Hei rocking his best impersonation of the Christian Bale Batman voice. I'd definitely recommend at least watching the first season as it is a staple of the darker action/thriller anime genre for a reason. You won't be disappointed in this Bones work. And I just gotta say that I still love me some Misaki.


8.5/10

Okay, firstly this anime rocks. I'm not joking, it's one of the most gripping and thrilling animes (for me) to date. Written and directed by Tensai Okamura and produced by Bones, this anime tells us the story of what happened as a result of a certain anomaly at 'Heavans Gate' in South America. As a result, at the opposite side of the world in Japan, 'Hells Gate' was opened and massive changes happened to the country.
The night sky is a reoccurring theme in this series. The real stars were replaced by false ones due to the opening of Hell's Gate. With these fake stars camethe Contractors. These are people [not sure if you can call them people as they have no emotions whatsoever but meh that's your decision] each have a different 'power' and a different price for that power. They have no emotions, they don't feel, they can only think rationally and what's in their best interest. As well as this, each Contractor has a corresponding star in the fake night sky, which allows the normal humans to track what each contracted is doing. Throughout the anime, the humans (that know of these Contractors) refer to them by their star names (eg BK-201 is the name for Hei). 

[getting a bit complex right?]


Hei is a member of an organisation known as 'The Syndicate'. This organisation is considered to be some underground group with no real motif. But as the series progresses it becomes apparent that it's operatives work with Contractors in order to regain peace in the world and they strive for the destruction of Hells Gate. 

In my opinion these is a lot of background knowledge needed to fully understand this anime, maybe rewatching season 1 before progressing to Ryūsei no Gemini would be more sensible than blindly binging on this show.

The characters really become noteworthy and it was a pleasure to watch this show. I personally didn't enjoy that I had to watch the episodes over and over again to fully understand it but I guess that's the beauty of it.

There's a fair share of humour, especially from Mao (a cat who talks) who's sarcasm is unrivalled  but on the other side of the table, there are copious amounts of genuinely heartfelt moments (mainly between Hei and Yin) that you as a viewer can really relate too. 


Please note that I neither have the energy, nor the words to fully review each and every character in this show.. Mainly as I'd give away quite a bit but also it's open to personal interpretation.. In my opinion this is a rare anime that should remain a favourite of mine for years to come.


Overall rating for this anime is a solid 9. It did get boring at times and it was somewhat predictable in places but my god was it brilliantly written. I think that it's the kind of anime that you watch on a rainy day (mainly as there's A LOT of rain in this anime, I dunno maybe it's just me)

Animation: 8/9

Music: 8

Storyline: 9

Rewatchability: Medium to High

Darker than Black is a masterpiece and a real treat for people who love a cool main character with superhuman abilities and big appetite. Fans of Code Geass will find familiar qualities in Darker than Black as well as its own unique features that make the story exciting and fun. A hero with a mask? A green-haired, white-jumpsuited girl? A superpower? Sounds familiar. These traits have made Code Geass great and are in Darker than Black as well!
The main character, Hei, has the stereotypical dual personality that most superheroes possess-- on the surface he is an ordinary transfer student, but underneath all of that isactually a contractor (people with special abilities given by the "Gate") who wears a black coat and mask and has been dubbed with the name, Black Reaper. Each character in the anime has a unique personality and past, and develops as the story progresses. The more you watch, the more you'll uncover secrets and events that make them who they are. Some big questions aren't answered until near the end, which only makes you want to watch more! Even the side characters are interesting, since it's always fun to find out what their powers are and what the price to that power is.\n\n
Each fight in the anime is intense and exciting, with excellent animation and epic background music, and every once and a while a fun episode or scene to lighten the mood. Action, mystery, humor, and even a little bit of romance, are deployed to make Darker than Black the best it can be. Overall, Darker than Black was very, very good, I just wished I could've seen more...

One of the major prerequisites for me to liking an anime and to be able continuing watching more than just a few episodes is that I must like or at least be able to stand the main character.
It's been a long time since I liked an MC this much. Hei (aka the grim reaper) basically defines what it takes to have a secret identity; to be able to be one person - a well-to-do, somewhat clueless, quiet guy - and to turn around and be someone completely different - a ruthless agent of death tracking down rouge 'contractors'. When you merge these two persona's youget a well matured individual whose really just seeking the truth. When you witness him in action you come to realize this is a guy whose very good at doing what needs to be done. There's no epic fights or drawn out discussions. 


The other characters in this series are well created as well, especially, the crew working with Hei. At first I thought they pulled the cliche with the talking cat, but there's a good reason for it and it adds for some good random humor relief. Huang, the older man, is another character I had to warm up to and eventually really liked. Kirihara is another good character which they really worked on throughout the whole show. Though, I don't think they made a big enough impact with Amber. Was she once Hei's love? How did they meet? What happened in between that S. America event and the time of the show?


The animation is above average. Thankfully there's no shortcuts with the action sequences and nothing seems to be recycled. I like how this is a show with super powers but unlike most, the super powers isn't the star of the show. The fight scenes are strategic, especially with the way Hei fights. Even if one of his knives miss...it doesn't really miss.


The story would be better if they explained more as to what the f*cks going on! By the end of it all I was kind of like "I think I get it...do I?" Animes have always been ambiguous with the 'why?'.



Overall 8/10.

Darker Than Black probably in my opinion one of the best underrated anime out there.
When the real starts disappeared 10 years ago, the sky was filled with false stars and two gates appeared one in Brazil and one in Tokyo, the on in Brazil was known as heaven's gate and the one in Tokyo was known as Hell's gate.
5 years after the gates had appeared, the one in Brazil was destroyed and it took much of South America with it.
During the time that the gates appeared people that have special abilities began to appear and they were known as Contractors.
Contractors are people with powers thatlost their humanity and they have to pay a price every time they use their powers.\n
These contractors work for various groups and organisations as spies and assassins.\n
The story follows a special contractor codenamed Hei as he takes on various jobs from his organisation.\n\n
The animation was awesome, the characters were awesome,the fight scenes were awesome, hell the whole anime was awesome.\n
Even tho is was a action/adventure type anime, there is a bit of comedy and you just can't help but wish that there were some romance between Hei and Yin.\n
If you're looking for an anime with a solid story, good animation and some great fight scenes, than this is the anime for you.\n
